title: acceptance criteria
description: Criteria associated with requirements, products, or the delivery cycle that must be met in order to achieve stakeholder acceptance.
sources: Agile Extension To The BABOK Guide

title: actor
description: A human, device, or system that plays some specified role in interacting with a solution.

title: adaptive approach
description: An approach where the solution evolves based on a cycle of learning and discovery, with feedback loops which encourage making decisions as late as possible.

title: artifact
description: Any solution-relevant object that is created as part of business analysis efforts.

title: assumption
description: An influencing factor that is believed to be true but has not been confirmed to be accurate, or that could be true now but may not be in the future.

title: behavioural business rule
description: BABOK: A business rule that places an obligation (or prohibition) on conduct, action, practice, or procedure; a business rule whose purpose is to shape (govern) day-to-day business activity. Also known as operative rule.

title: behavioural characteristics
description: Your demonstrated character traits on the job that are observed by others or by you.

title: benchmarking
description: A comparison of a decision, process, service, or system's cost, time, quality, or other metrics to those of leading peers to identify opportunities for improvement.

title: body of knowledge
description: The aggregated knowledge and generally accepted practices on a topic.

title: brainstorming
description: A team activity that seeks to produce a broad or diverse set of options through the rapid and uncritical generation of ideas.

title: business (business analysis)
description: See enterprise

title: business analysis
description: The practice of enabling change in the context of an enterprise by defining needs and recommending solutions that deliver value to stakeholders.

title: business analysis approach
description: The set of processes, rules, guidelines, heuristics, and activities that are used to perform business analysis in a specific context.

title: business analysis communication plan
description: A description of the types of communication the business analyst will perform during business analysis, the recipients of those communications, and the form and frequency of those communications.

title: business analysis effort
description: The scope of activities a business analyst is engaged in during the life cycle of an initiative.

title: business analysis information
description: Any kind of information at any level of detail that is used as an input to business analysis work, or as an output of business analysis work.

title: business analysis package
description: A document, presentation, or other collection of text, matrices, diagrams and models, representing business analysis information.

title: business analysis plan
description: A description of the planned activities the business analyst will execute in order to perform the business analysis work involved in a specific initiative.

title: business analyst
description: Any person who performs business analysis, no matter their job title or organizational role.

title: business case
description: A justification for a course of action based on the benefits to be realized by using the proposed solution, as compared to the cost, effort, and other considerations to acquire and live with that solution.

title: business decision
description: A decision that can be made based on strategy, executive judgment, consensus, and business rules, and that is generally made in response to events or at defined points in a business process.

title: business domain
description: See domain.
sources: Agile Extension To The BABOK Guide

title: business (business world)
description: An economic system where any commercial, industrial, or professional activity is performed for profit.

title: business goal
description: A state or condition that an organization is seeking to establish and maintain, usually expressed qualitatively rather than quantitatively.
sources: Agile Extension To The BABOK Guide

title: business need
description: A problem or opportunity of strategic or tactical importance to be addressed.

title: business objective
description: An objective, measurable result to indicate that a business goal has been achieved.
sources: Agile Extension To The BABOK Guide

title: business policy
description: A non-practicable directive that controls and influences the actions of an enterprise.

title: business problem
description: An issue of strategic or tactical importance preventing an enterprise or organization from achieving its goals.

title: business process
description: An end-to-end set of activities which collectively responds to an event, and transforms information, materials, and other resources into outputs that deliver value directly to the customers of the process. It may be internal to an organization, or it may span several organizations.

title: business process management
description: A management discipline that determines how manual and automated processes are created, modified, cancelled, and governed.

title: business process re-engineering
description: Rethinking and redesigning business processes to generate improvements in performance measures.

title: business requirement
description: A representation of goals, objectives and outcomes that describe why a change has been initiated and how success will be assessed.

title: business rule
description: SBVR: rule that is practicable and that is under business jurisdiction
sources: Agile Extension To The BABOK Guide

title: capability
description: The set of activities the enterprise performs, the knowledge it has, the products and services it provides, the functions it supports, and the methods it uses to make decisions.

title: cause-and-effect diagram
description: See fishbone diagram.

title: change
description: The act of transformation in response to a need.

title: change agent
description: One who is a catalyst for change.

title: change control
description: Controlling changes to requirements and designs so that the impact of requested changes is understood and agreed-to before the changes are made.

title: change management
description: Planned activities, tools, and techniques to address the human side of change during a change initiative, primarily addressing the needs of the people who will be most affected by the change.

title: change strategy
description: A plan to move from the current state to the future state to achieve the desired business objectives.

title: change team
description: A cross-functional group of individuals who are mandated to implement a change. This group may be comprised of product owners, business analysts, developers, project managers, implementation subject matter experts (SMEs), or any other individual with the relevant set of skills and competencies required to implement the change.

title: checklist (business analysis)
description: A standard set of quality elements that reviewers use for requirements verification.

title: collaboration
description: The act of two or more people working together towards a common goal.
sources: Agile Extension To The BABOK Guide

title: commercial off-the-shelf
description: A prepackaged solution available in the marketplace which address all or most of the common needs of a large group of buyers of those solutions. A commercial off-the-shelf solution may require some configuration to meet the specific needs of the enterprise.

title: competitive analysis
description: A structured assessment which captures the key characteristics of an industry to predict the long-term profitability prospects and to determine the practices of the most significant competitors.

title: component
description: A uniquely identifiable element of a larger whole that fulfills a clear function.

title: concept model
description: An analysis model that develops the meaning of core concepts for a problem domain, defines their collective structure, and specifies the appropriate vocabulary needed to communicate about it consistently.

title: constraint (business analysis)
description: An influencing factor that cannot be changed, and that places a limit or restriction on a possible solution or solution option.
sources: Agile Extension To The BABOK Guide

title: context
description: The circumstances that influence, are influenced by, and provide understanding of the change.
sources: Agile Extension To The BABOK Guide

title: core_concept_(business_analysis)
description: One of six ideas that are fundamental to the practice of business analysis: Change, Need, Solution, Context, Stakeholder, and Value.

title: cost-benefit analysis
description: An analysis which compares and quantifies the financial and non-financial costs of making a change or implementing a solution compared to the benefits gained.

title: create, read, update, and delete matrix
description: A two-dimensional matrix showing which user roles have permission to access specific information entities, and to create new records in those entities, view the data in existing records, update or modify the data in existing records, or delete existing records. The same type of matrix can be used to show which processes, instead of users, have the create, read, update and delete rights.

title: customer
description: A stakeholder who uses or may use products or services produced by the enterprise and may have contractual or moral rights that the enterprise is obliged to meet.
sources: Agile Extension To The BABOK Guide

title: decision analysis
description: An approach to decision making that examines and models the possible consequences of different decisions, and assists in making an optimal decision under conditions of uncertainty.
sources: Agile Extension To The BABOK Guide

title: decomposition
description: A technique that subdivides a problem into its component parts in order to facilitate analysis and understanding of those components.

title: definitional business rule
description: BABOK: A rule that indicates something is necessarily true (or untrue); a rule that is intended as a definitional criterion for concepts, knowledge, or information. Also known as a structural rule.

title: deliverable
description: Any unique and verifiable work product or service that a party has agreed to deliver.

title: design
description: A usable representation of a solution. For more information see Key Terms and Requirements and Designs.
sources: Agile Extension To The BABOK Guide

title: document analysis (business analysis)
description: An examination of the documentation of an existing system in order to elicit requirements.

title: domain
description: The sphere of knowledge that defines a set of common requirements, terminology, and functionality for any program or initiative solving a problem.
sources: Agile Extension To The BABOK Guide

title: domain subject matter expert
description: A stakeholder with in-depth knowledge of a topic relevant to the business need or solution scope.

title: dynamic systems development method
description: A project delivery framework which focuses on fixing cost, quality, and time at the beginning while contingency is managed by varying the features to be delivered.

title: elicitation
description: Iterative derivation and extraction of information from stakeholders or other sources.

title: end user
description: A stakeholder who directly interacts with the solution.

title: enterprise
description: A system of one or more organizations and the solutions they use to pursue a shared set of common goals.

title: enterprise readiness assessment
description: An assessment that describes the enterprise is prepared to accept the change associated with a solution and is able to use it effectively.

title: entity-relationship diagram
description: A graphical representation of the entities relevant to a chosen problem domain and the relationships between them.

title: estimate
description: A quantitative assessment of a planned outcome, resource requirements, and schedule where uncertainties and unknowns are systematically factored into the assessment.

title: evaluation
description: The systematic and objective assessment of a solution to determine its status and efficacy in meeting objectives over time, and to  identify ways to improve the solution to better meet objectives. See also indicator; metric, monitoring.

title: event (business analysis)
description: An occurrence or incident to which an organizational unit, system, or process must respond.

title: evolutionary prototype
description: A prototype that is continuously modified and updated in response to feedback from stakeholders.

title: experiment
description: Elicitation performed in a controlled manner to make a discovery, test a hypothesis, or demonstrate a known fact.
sources: Agile Extension To The BABOK Guide

title: external interface
description: An interaction that is outside the proposed solution. It can be another hardware system, software system, or a human interaction with which the proposed solution will interact.

title: facilitation
description: The art of leading and encouraging people through systematic efforts toward agreed-upon objectives in a manner that enhances involvement, collaboration, productivity, and synergy.

title: feasibility study
description: An evaluation of proposed alternatives to determine if they are technically, organizationally, and economically possible within the constraints of the enterprise, and whether they will deliver the desired benefits to the enterprise.

title: feature
description: A distinguishing characteristic of a solution that implements a cohesive set of requirements and which delivers value for a set of stakeholders.
sources: Agile Extension To The BABOK Guide

title: fishbone diagram
description: A diagramming technique used in root cause analysis to identify underlying causes of an observed problem, and the relationships that exist between those causes. Also known as an Ishikawa or cause-and-effect diagram.

title: focus group
description: A group formed to elicit ideas and attitudes about a specific product, service, or opportunity in an interactive group environment. The participants share their impressions, preferences, and needs, guided by a moderator.

title: force field analysis
description: A graphical method for depicting the forces that support and oppose a change. Involves identifying the forces, depicting them on opposite sides of a line (supporting and opposing forces) and then estimating the strength of each set of forces.

title: functional requirement
description: A capability that a solution must have in terms of the behaviour and information the solution will manage.

title: gap analysis
description: A comparison of the current state and desired future state of an enterprise in order to identify differences that need to be addressed.

title: goal
description: See business goal.
sources: Agile Extension To The BABOK Guide

title: governance process (change)
description: A process by which appropriate decision makers use relevant information to make decisions regarding a change or solution, including the means for obtaining approvals and priorities.

title: guideline (business analysis)
description: An instruction or description on why or how to undertake a task.

title: horizontal prototype
description: A prototype that is used to explore requirements and designs at one level of a proposed solution, such as the customer-facing view or the interface to another organization.

title: impact analysis
description: An assessment of the effects a proposed change will have on a stakeholder or stakeholder group, project, or system.

title: implementation subject matter expert
description: A stakeholder who has specialized knowledge regarding the implementation of one or more solution components.

title: indicator
description: A specific numerical measurement that indicates progress toward achieving an impact, output, activity, or input. See also metric.

title: initiative
description: A specific project, program, or action taken to solve some business problem(s) or achieve some specific change objective(s).
sources: Agile Extension To The BABOK Guide

title: input (business analysis)
description: Information consumed or transformed to produce an output. An input is the information necessary for a task to begin.

title: inspection
description: A formal review of a work product by qualified individuals that follows a predefined process, and uses predefined criteria, for defect identification and removal.

title: interface
description: A shared boundary between any two persons and/or systems through which information is communicated.

title: interoperability
description: Ability of systems to communicate by exchanging data or services.

title: interview
description: Eliciting information from a person or group of people in an informal or formal setting by asking relevant questions and recording the responses.

title: Ishikawa diagram
description: See fishbone diagram.

title: iteration (business analysis)
description: A single instance of progressive cycles of analysis, development, testing, or execution.

title: knowledge area (business analysis)
description: An area of expertise that includes several specific business analysis tasks.

title: lessons learned process
description: A process improvement technique used to learn about and improve on a process or project. A lessons learned session involves a special meeting in which the team explores what worked, what didn't work, what could be learned from the just-completed iteration, and how to adapt processes and techniques before continuing or starting anew.

title: life_cycle
description: A series of changes an item or object undergoes from inception to retirement.

title: matrix
description: A textual form of modelling used to represent information that can be categorized, cross-referenced, and represented in a table format.

title: metadata
description: A description of data to help understand how to use that data, either in terms of the structure and specification of the data, or the description of a specific instance of an object.

title: methodology
description: A body of methods, techniques, procedures, working concepts, and rules used to solve a problem.
sources: Agile Extension To The BABOK Guide

title: metric
description: A quantifiable level of an indicator measured at a specified point in time.
sources: Agile Extension To The BABOK Guide

title: mission statement
description: A formal declaration of values and goals that expresses the core purpose of the enterprise.

title: model
description: A representation and simplification of reality developed to convey information to a specific audience to support analysis, communication, and understanding.
sources: Agile Extension To The BABOK Guide

title: monitoring
description: Collecting data on a continuous basis from a solution in order to determine how well a solution is implemented compared to expected results. See also metric; indicator.

title: need
description: A problem or opportunity to be addressed.
sources: Agile Extension To The BABOK Guide

title: non-functional requirement
description: A type of requirement that describes the performance or quality attributes a solution must meet. Non-functional requirements are usually measurable and act as constraints on the design of a solution as a whole.

title: objective
description: See business objective.
sources: Agile Extension To The BABOK Guide

title: observation (business analysis)
description: Studying and analyzing one or more stakeholders in their work environment in order to elicit requirements.

title: online analytical processing
description: A business intelligence approach that allows users to analyze large amounts of data from different points of view.

title: operational support
description: A stakeholder who is responsible for the day-to-day management and maintenance of a system or product.

title: operative business rule
description: See behavioural business rule.

title: organization
description: An autonomous group of people under the management of a single individual or board, that works towards common goals and objectives.

title: organizational capability
description: A function inside the enterprise, made up of components such as processes, technologies, and information and used by organizations to achieve their goals.

title: organizational unit
description: Any recognized association of people within an organization or enterprise.

title: organization modelling
description: The analysis technique used to describe roles, responsibilities and reporting structures that exist within an enterprise.

title: peer_review
description: A formal or informal review of a work product to identify errors or opportunities for improvement. See also inspection.

title: plan
description: A detailed scheme for doing or achieving something usually comprising a set of events, dependencies, expected sequence, schedule, results or outcomes, materials and resources needed, and how stakeholders need to be involved.

title: predictive approach
description: An approach where planning and baselines are established early in the life cycle of the initiative in order to maximize control and minimize risk.

title: prioritization
description: Determining the relative importance of a set of items in order to determine the order in which they will be addressed.

title: process
description: A set of activities designed to accomplish a specific objective by taking one or more defined inputs and turning them into defined outputs.

title: process model
description: A set of diagrams and supporting information about a process and factors that could influence the process. Some process models are used to simulate the performance of the process.

title: product (business analysis)
description: A solution or component of a solution that is the result of an initiative.
sources: Agile Extension To The BABOK Guide

title: product backlog
description: A set of user stories, requirements, or features that have been identified as candidates for potential implementation, prioritized, and estimated.

title: product vision statement
description: A brief statement or paragraph that describes the goals of the solution and how it supports the strategy of the organization or enterprise.

title: project
description: A temporary endeavour undertaken to create a unique product, service, or result.

title: project manager
description: A stakeholder who is responsible for managing the work required to deliver a solution that meets a business need, and for ensuring that the project's objectives are met while balancing the project constraints, including scope, budget, schedule, resources, quality, and risk.

title: project scope
description: The work that must be performed to deliver a product, service, or result with the specified features and functions.

title: proof_of_concept
description: A model created to validate the design of a solution without modelling the appearance, materials used in the creation of work, or processes and workflows ultimately used by the stakeholders.

title: prototype
description: A partial or simulated approximation of the solution for the purpose of eliciting or verifying requirements with stakeholders.

title: quality
description: The degree to which a set of inherent characteristics fulfills needs.

title: quality assurance
description: set of activities performed to ensure that a process will deliver products that meet an appropriate level of quality.

title: quality attributes
description: A set of measures used to judge the overall quality of a system. See also non-functional requirements.

title: questionnaire
description: A set of defined questions, with a choice of answers, used to collect information from respondents.

title: regulator
description: A stakeholder from outside the organization who is responsible for the definition and enforcement of standards.

title: repository
description: A real or virtual facility where all information on a specific topic is stored and is available for retrieval.

title: request for information
description: A formal elicitation method intended to collect information regarding a vendor's capabilities or any other information relevant to a potential upcoming procurement.

title: request for proposal
description: A requirements document issued when an organization is seeking a formal proposal from vendors. An RFP typically requires that the proposals be submitted following a specific process and using sealed bids which will be evaluated against a formal evaluation methodology.

title: request for quote
description: A procurement method of soliciting price and solution options from vendors.

title: request for tender
description: An open invitation to vendors to submit a proposal for goods or services.

title: requirement
description: A usable representation of a need.
sources: Agile Extension To The BABOK Guide

title: requirements allocation
description: The process of assigning requirements to be implemented by specific solution components.

title: requirements artifact
description: A business analysis artifact containing information about requirements such as a diagram, matrix, document or model.

title: requirements attribute
description: A characteristic or property of a requirement used to assist with requirements management.

title: requirements defect
description: A problem or error in a requirement. Defects may occur because a requirement is poor quality (see requirements verification) or because it does not describe a need that, if met, would provide value to stakeholders (see requirements validation).

title: requirements life cycle
description: The stages through which a requirement progresses from inception to retirement.

title: requirements management
description: Planning, executing, monitoring, and controlling any or all of the work associated with requirements elicitation and collaboration, requirements analysis and design, and requirements life cycle management.

title: requirements management plan
description: A subset of the business analysis plan for a specific change initiative, describing specific tools, activities, and roles and responsibilities that will be used on the initiative to manage the requirements.

title: requirements management tool
description: Special-purpose software that provides support for any combination of the following capabilities: elicitation and collaboration, requirements modelling and/or specification, requirements traceability, versioning and baselining, attribute definition for tracking and monitoring, document generation, and requirements change control.

title: requirements model
description: An abstract (usually graphical) representation of some aspect of the current or future state.

title: requirements package
description: A specialized form of a business analysis package primarily concerned with requirements. A requirements package may represent a baseline of a collection of requirements.

title: requirements traceability
description: The ability for tracking the relationships between sets of requirements and designs from the original stakeholder need to the actual implemented solution. Traceability supports change control by ensuring that the source of a requirement or design can be identified and other related requirements and designs potentially affected by a change are known.

title: requirements validation
description: Work done to evaluate requirements to ensure they support the delivery of the expected benefits and are within the solution scope.

title: requirements verification
description: Work done to evaluate requirements to ensure they are defined correctly and are at an acceptable level of quality. It ensures the requirements are sufficiently defined and structured so that the solution development team can use them in the design, development, and implementation of the solution.

title: requirements workshop
description: A structured meeting in which a carefully selected group of stakeholders collaborate to define and/or refine requirements under the guidance of a skilled neutral facilitator.

title: residual risk
description: The risk remaining after action has been taken or plans have been put in place to deal with the original risk.

title: return on investment (business analysis)
description: A measure of the profitability of a project or investment.

title: risk (business analysis)
description: The effect of uncertainty on the value of a change, a solution, or the enterprise. See also residual risk.
sources: Agile Extension To The BABOK Guide

title: risk assessment
description: Identifying, analyzing and evaluating risks.

title: root cause
description: The cause of a problem having no deeper cause, usually one of several possible causes.

title: root cause analysis
description: A structured examination of an identified problem to understand the underlying causes.

title: scope
description: The boundaries of control, change, a solution, or a need.

title: scope model
description: A model that defines the boundaries of a business domain or solution.

title: secondary actor
description: An actor external to the system under design that supports the execution of a use case.

title: sequence diagram
description: A type of diagram that shows objects participating in interactions and the messages exchanged between them.

title: service (business analysis)
description: The performance of any duties or work for a stakeholder, from the perspective of the stakeholder.

title: software engineer
description: See developer.

title: solution
description: A specific way of satisfying one or more needs in a context.
sources: Agile Extension To The BABOK Guide

title: solution component
description: A sub-part of a solution that can be people, infrastructure, hardware, software, equipment, facilities, and process assets or any combination of these sub-parts.

title: solution life cycle
description: The stages through which a solution progresses from inception to retirement.

title: solution option
description: One possible way to satisfy one or more needs in a context.

title: solution requirement
description: A capability or quality of a solution that meets the stakeholder requirements. Solution requirements can be divided into two sub-categories: functional requirements and non-functional requirements or quality of service requirements.

title: solution scope
description: The set of capabilities a solution must deliver in order to meet the business need.

title: sponsor
description: A stakeholder who is responsible for initiating the effort to define a business need and develop a solution that meets that need. They authorize the work to be performed and control the budget and scope for the initiative.

title: stakeholder
description: A group or individual with a relationship to the change, the need, or the solution.
sources: Agile Extension To The BABOK Guide

title: stakeholder analysis
description: Identifying and analyzing the stakeholders who may be impacted by the change and assess their impact, participation, and needs throughout the business analysis activities.

title: stakeholder list
description: A catalogue of the stakeholders affected by a change, business need, or proposed solution, and a description of their attributes and characteristics related to their involvement in the initiative.

title: stakeholder proxy (business analyst)
description: The role a business analyst takes when representing the needs of a stakeholder or stakeholder group.

title: stakeholder_requirement
description: A description of the needs of a particular stakeholder or class of stakeholders that must be met in order to achieve the business requirements. They may serve as a bridge between business requirements and the various categories of solution requirements.

title: stated requirement
description: A requirement articulated by a stakeholder that has not been analyzed, verified, or validated. Stated requirements frequently reflect the desires of a stakeholder rather than the actual need.

title: statement of work
description: A written description of the services or tasks that are required to be performed.

title: state diagram
description: An analysis model showing the life cycle of a data entity or class.
sources: Agile Extension To The BABOK Guide

title: strategy
description: A description of the chosen approach to apply the capabilities of an enterprise in order to reach a desired set of goals or objectives.

title: structural rule
description: See definitional business rule.

title: subject matter expert
description: See domain subject matter expert; implementation subject matter expert.

title: supplier
description: A stakeholder outside the boundary of a given organization or organizational unit who provides products or services to the organization and may have contractual or moral rights and obligations that must be considered.

title: survey
description: Collecting and measuring the opinions or experiences of a group of people through a series of questions.

title: swimlane
description: A horizontal or vertical section of a process diagram that shows which activities are performed by a particular actor or role.

title: system
description: A set of interdependent components that interact in various ways to produce a set of desired outcomes.

title: task (business analysis)
description: A discrete piece of work that may be performed formally or informally as part of business analysis.

title: technique
description: A manner, method, or style for conducting a business analysis task or for shaping its output.

title: temporal_event
description: An event based on time that can trigger the initiation of a process, evaluation of business rules, or some other response.

title: tester
description: An individual responsible for determining how to verify that the solution meets the requirements defined by the business analyst, and conducting the verification process.

title: throw-away prototype
description: A prototype used to quickly uncover and clarify requirements or designs using simple tools, sometimes just paper and pencil. It is intended to be discarded when the final system has been developed.

title: time-box
description: An agreed-upon period of time in which an activity is conducted or a defined deliverable is intended to be produced.
sources: Agile Extension To The BABOK Guide

title: transition requirement
description: A requirement that describes the capabilities the solution must have and the conditions the solution must meet to facilitate transition from the current state to the future state, but which are not needed once the change is complete. They are differentiated from other requirements types because they are of a temporary nature.

title: unified modelling language
description: A notation specified by the Object Management Group for describing software application structure, behaviour, and architecture. It can also be used for describing business processes and data structures. The most common UML diagrams used by business analysts are use case diagrams, activity diagrams, state machine diagrams (also known as state diagrams), and class diagrams.

title: user acceptance test
description: Assessing whether the delivered solution meets the needs of the stakeholder group that will be using the solution. The assessment is validated against identified acceptance criteria.

title: user story
description: A small, concise statement of functionality or quality needed to deliver value to a specific stakeholder.
sources: Agile Extension To The BABOK Guide

title: use case
description: A description of the observable interaction between an actor (or actors) and a solution that occurs when the actor uses the system to accomplish a specific goal.

title: use case diagram
description: A type of diagram defined by UML that captures all actors and use cases involved with a system or product.

title: validated requirement
description: A requirement that has been reviewed and is determined to support the delivery of the expected benefits, and is within the solution scope.

title: validation (business analysis)
description: The process of checking that a deliverable is suitable for its intended use. See also requirements validation.

title: value (business analysis)
description: The worth, importance, or usefulness of something to a stakeholder in a context.
sources: Agile Extension To The BABOK Guide

title: value stream mapping
description: A complete, fact-based, time-series representation of the stream of activities required to deliver a product or service.

title: verification (business analysis)
description: The process of determining that a deliverable or artifact meets an acceptable standard of quality. See also requirements verification.

title: verified requirement
description: A requirement that has been reviewed and is determined to be defined correctly, adheres to standards or guidelines, and is at an acceptable level of detail.

title: vertical prototype
description: A prototype that is used to drill down into a proposed solution to uncover requirement and design considerations through multiple layers of a solution that are not easily understood or that are not discernible on the surface. It may include interaction between several solution components.

title: viewpoint
description: A set of conventions that define how requirements will be represented, how these representations will be organized, and how they will be related.

title: walkthrough
description: A review in which participants step through an artifact or set of artifacts with the intention of validating the requirements or designs, and to identify requirements or design errors, inconsistencies, omissions, inaccuracies, or conflicts.

title: workshop
description: A facilitated and focused event attended by key stakeholders for the purpose of achieving a defined goal.

title: work breakdown structure
description: A deliverable-oriented hierarchical decomposition of the work to be executed to accomplish objectives and create the required deliverables. It organizes and defines the total scope of the project.

title: work product (business analysis)
description: A document or collection of notes or diagrams used by the business analyst during the requirements development process.

title: business architecture
description: The design, structure, and behavior of the current and future states of an enterprise to provide a common understanding of the organization. It is used to align the enterprises strategic objectives and tactical demands.

title: enterprise_architecture
description: A description of the business processes, information technology, people, operations, information, and projects of an enterprise and the relationships between them.

title: requirements_architecture
description: The requirements of an initiative and the interrelationships between these requirements.

title: architecture
description: The design, structure, and behaviour of the current and future states of a structure in terms of its components, and the interaction between those components. See also business architecture, enterprise architecture, and requirements architecture.
